awd_titl_txt: RCN: Learning from Indigenous community-based researchers engaged in science around the Arctic

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Arctic research in and about communities depends in large part on collaborations, especially with local researchers, whose roles have often been taken for granted. The approach of this Research Collaboration Network (RCN) stressed the interests and needs for Indigenous community-based researchers to meet their counterparts in Arctic homelands and to design research network activities in their own locally and culturally relevant ways, and not necessarily just through table-based meetings in rooms that could be anywhere. This approach acknowledged that not only are groups underrepresented or marginalized in science, but so are their ways for doing science and producing and exchanging knowledge. Our RCN worked to support this by creating a network of community-based researchers through a series of in-person meetings held in small communities across the Arctic and through maintaining connections via available and accessible technology between meetings. This has allowed for the network to exchange knowledge, experiences and support one another not only in research but in many aspects of their livelihoods and lives. 

Establishing a network of Indigenous community-based researchers like this RCN in the Arctic can have a number of broader impacts for northern science and society and beyond. The connections built between the researchers themselves is strengthening knowledge, circulating methods and approaches, and enhancing Indigenous leadership skills in Arctic research and education and more. Forming such a network gives recognition to the importance of the work these researchers and practitioners are already doing and the ways in which they are doing it, and also gives these knowledge-holders, experts, and their roles greater prominence in Arctic science. An RCN like this has the potential to create a support system for the next generation of researchers, both those who live in Indigenous communities and those who visit the Arctic, to conduct high quality community-based research in full awareness of the importance of Indigenous knowledge and expertise available in Arctic communities.
